title: 110_hr731
content: The "National Small Business Regulatory Assistance Act of 2007" aims to provide confidential assistance to small businesses, help them improve compliance with regulations, create partnerships among federal agencies for outreach, offer unbiased feedback on the regulatory environment, and utilize Small Business Development Centers for regulatory compliance programs. The Act defines terms according to the Small Business Act and establishes a Small Business Regulatory Assistance Program under section 37. The Small Business Regulatory Assistance Program under section 37 defines key terms such as Association, Participating small business development center, Program, Regulatory compliance assistance, and Small business development center. The Small Business Regulatory Assistance Program defines key terms and establishes a program to provide regulatory compliance assistance to small business concerns through selected Small Business Development Centers, the Association of Small Business Development Centers, and Federal compliance partnership programs. The Small Business Development Centers offer access to information, training, counseling, and technical assistance to small business owners for compliance with Federal and State regulations. The Small Business Development Centers provide regulatory compliance assistance, technical assistance, referrals to experts, and Internet access and training. Each center must submit quarterly reports summarizing the assistance provided. The Small Business Development Centers must submit quarterly reports summarizing assistance provided, including data from Federal agencies on regulatory compliance for dissemination to small businesses in electronic form. Interim reports can also be submitted as deemed appropriate, with a limitation on disclosing specific information. The Small Business Development Centers must submit quarterly reports summarizing assistance provided, including data from Federal agencies on regulatory compliance for dissemination to small businesses in electronic form. The Administrator acts as a repository and clearinghouse for data and information submitted by the Centers, submitting an annual report to relevant committees. The Small Business Development Centers submit quarterly reports summarizing assistance provided, including data on regulatory compliance. The annual report includes descriptions of assistance types, data on contacted small businesses, number of assisted businesses, and outreach activities conducted by the Centers. The Small Business Development Centers submit quarterly reports summarizing assistance provided, including data on regulatory compliance, conflicting advice, recommendations for improvements in regulations, and a list of identified regulations. The Chief Counsel for Advocacy of the Administration reviews a list of regulations deemed burdensome to small businesses and makes recommendations to reduce or eliminate these burdens. Additionally, an Internet website is established to provide access to industry-specific regulatory compliance information for small businesses. The Administrator transmits a list of burdensome regulations to the Chief Counsel for Advocacy for review. The Chief Counsel identifies regulations eligible for review and with significant impact on small businesses. The Chief Counsel for Advocacy reviews regulations with significant impact on small businesses, notifying the appropriate agencies and conducting agency reviews. The Chief Counsel for Advocacy reviews regulations impacting small businesses, requesting agency reviews and publishing an annual report on identified regulations. Small Business Development Centers must be certified to receive assistance under the program. The Administrator may waive certification requirements for Small Business Development Centers if a good faith effort is being made. The restriction on certification does not apply before October 1, 2007. The Administrator, in consultation with the Association, selects two State programs from each group to participate in the program. The Administrator selects two State programs from each of the following groups to participate in the program: Group 1 - Maine, Massachusetts, New Hampshire, Connecticut, Vermont, and Rhode Island; Group 2 - New York, New Jersey, Puerto Rico, and the Virgin Islands; Group 3 - Pennsylvania, Maryland, West Virginia, Virginia, the District of Columbia, and Delaware; Group 4 - Georgia, Alabama, North Carolina, South Carolina, Mississippi, Florida, Kentucky, and Tennessee; Group 5 - Illinois, Ohio, Michigan, Indiana, Wisconsin, and Minnesota; Group 6 - Texas, New Mexico, Arkansas, Oklahoma, and Louisiana; Group 7 - Missouri, Iowa, Nebraska, and Kansas. The Administrator selects State programs from different groups to participate in the program, with deadlines for selections and the possibility of additional selections after three years. The Administrator selects State programs to participate in the program, considering the effect on existing programs before selecting additional ones. Preference is given to Small Business Development Center programs that coordinate with Federal and State agencies to avoid duplication. Matching funds are not required for assistance under the program, and grants are distributed according to specified guidelines. Each State program selected for a grant under subsection (g) is eligible to receive an amount based on the state's population compared to all states with programs selected. The minimum grant amount is $250,000. The Administrator may adjust the grant amount to ensure program effectiveness. The program evaluation and report will be conducted by the Comptroller General of the United States within 3 years of its establishment. A report with recommendations will be submitted to the Administrator and relevant committees. $6,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2008 and subsequent years to carry out the program. The Administrator shall carry out the program with appropriated funds only. SEC. 5. PROMULGATION OF REGULATIONS. After consulting with the Association, the Administrator will promulgate final regulations within 180 days to establish priorities for assistance, standards for services by Small Business Development Centers, national service delivery standards, work plan requirements, and educational and technical standards. Standards for the competency of experts or assistance providers referred to small businesses for compliance assistance under the program will be established.
